author: doxos9414
content:
Question about oracles: When uploading a new turing complete contract into the network (with potentially undefined, though deterministic behaviors), how is that different than an oracle affecting the history of the network?

In both situations, you're allowing potentially random data with random behaviors at random times, into the network... The uploading of those undefined behaviors in contracts are not deterministic. However, after they're read in, subsequent operations on that data are deterministic, so that makes sense to me.

My question is, why can't the same thing make sense for a json doc? After it is read in, subsequent operations on that data can still be deterministic...

Apologies if this is a stupid question. I'm not new to these kinds of threat models and deterministic behavior but I'm a little bit new to contract based blockchains and I'm just now getting my feet wet, so my assumptions could be naive. Thanks!

author: doxos9414
content: I mean I get why you wouldn't want every node on the network duplicating some interaction with the outside world, so you need to direct that execution to one or a few nodes in a safe way, but why just punt on that problem and let another network handle it? Why wouldn't I just use that other network to begin with?

author: doxos9414
content: If it's so trustworthy and is capable of computing contracts as well...
